We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.
We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.
Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.
Support with working in the UK during and after your studies, where to find up-to-date visa advice and working overseas.
Advice on career options for PhD students, marketing yourself effectively and details of our PhD Careers Programme.
Details of our tailored support for graduates, toolkits to help your career development and advice on adapting to the professional world.
We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background. Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility.
We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background.
Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility.

We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.

Recent graduates 





Details of our tailored support for graduates, toolkits to help your career development and advice on adapting to the professional world. 











 













Inclusive careers 





We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background. Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility.

Tuition fees
Student-led tours, virtual visit and open days. Join us!
No matter if you're interested in on-campus or online postgraduate programmes, talk to our current students about their experiences.
Learn about our different types of research degree, how to find a research supervisor, and where to look for funding opportunities.
Our taught degrees enable you to expand your field of knowledge, or acquire expertise in an area that you haven’t studied before.
Study anywhere in the world, at times that suit you, for an internationally recognised postgraduate certificate, diploma or masters degree.

pages.content:
[HEADING] Welcome to your Careers Service
[HEADING] CVs & applications
[HEADING] Jobs & internships
[HEADING] Explore your options
[HEADING] Interviews
[HEADING] Build experience
[HEADING] What's on
[HEADING] Careers support for everyone
[HEADING] International students
[HEADING] PhD and MRes students
[HEADING] Recent graduates
[HEADING] Inclusive careers
We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.
We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.
Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.
Support with working in the UK during and after your studies, where to find up-to-date visa advice and working overseas.
Advice on career options for PhD students, marketing yourself effectively and details of our PhD Careers Programme.
Details of our tailored support for graduates, toolkits to help your career development and advice on adapting to the professional world.
We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background. Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility.
We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background.
Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility.

          2024-05-14

Welcome to your Careers Service


We are here to support you to take your next steps with confidence, whatever stage you are at. Our online expert careers advice, information, tools and resources are available for you to use anytime and anywhere.Not sure where to begin? We've got you covered! Your next steps will depend on what stage you are currently at.


 

        Where are you now?
                              











 






CVs & applications 












Writing an effective CV 
Completing an application form 
Creating a LinkedIn profile 









Jobs & internships 












Part-time & vacation jobs 
Graduate jobs 
Create your own opportunity  









Explore your options  












Making and changing plans  
Find out about different careers 
Start your career planning  









 






Interviews  












Prepare for interview  
Assessment centres 
Selection tests 









Build experience 












Volunteer 
Edinburgh Award  
Develop your skills  









What's on 












Fairs, themed events & campaigns  
Career Essentials workshops  
Masters Careers programme  









 
Careers support for everyone





 













International students 





Support with working in the UK during and after your studies, where to find up-to-date visa advice and working overseas.


















PhD and MRes students 





Advice on career options for PhD students, marketing yourself effectively and details of our PhD Careers Programme. 


















Recent graduates 





Details of our tailored support for graduates, toolkits to help your career development and advice on adapting to the professional world. 











 













Inclusive careers 





We’re committed to supporting all of our students and recent graduates to achieve satisfying and rewarding futures, regardless of who you are or your background. Explore how we can support students who may face additional barriers accessing opportunities, how to have open conversations about personal disclosure in professional settings, and our commitments to accessibility. 









        Information for staff
                              




        Information for employers
                              




        About the Careers Service

pages.content:
[HEADING] Funding your studies
[HEADING] Loans
[HEADING] Scholarships
[HEADING] Other sources of funding
Most postgraduate students combine funding from a variety of sources to fund their fees and living costs, such as loans, scholarships and income from work.
Funding for postgraduate study is different to undergraduate study, and many students need to combine funding sources to pay for their studies.
Most students use a combination of funding sources to pay their tuition fees and living costs:
The two main types of loan for postgraduate study are government-backed loans and private bank loans.
The University of Edinburgh and other institutions offer scholarships you can apply for to cover some of your postgraduate study costs.
You can explore funding your studies through income from work, grants or employer sponsorship.
This article was published on
          2024-11-12

pages.content:
[HEADING] Tuition fee deposits
[HEADING] Deposit deadlines
[HEADING] Deposit refunds
[HEADING] Making a refund request
[HEADING] Deposit exemptions
[HEADING] Transferring deposits
[HEADING] Deferrals
[HEADING] School and college deposit policies
Some of our postgraduate taught programmes require you to pay a deposit.
The deposit will be offset against your tuition fee, and is a minimum payment. You can opt to pay more of your tuition fee in advance if you want to.
Deposits can vary, but full-time programmes are normally charged at:
If a deposit is required, it will be listed in the Fees and Costs section of your programme page on our postgraduate degree finder.
Visit our postgraduate degree finder
The deadline for paying your deposit will be included in your offer letter, and will vary depending on your chosen programme. If you fail to pay your deposit by the stated deadline, your offer may be withdrawn.
If you are having difficulty meeting our deposit deadline, please contact your admissions team. A deadline extension can be granted at the discretion of your school or college.
Contact details for your admissions team are provided on your programme page in our postgraduate degree finder.
Find contact details in our postgraduate degree finder
Deposit refunds can only be made in the following circumstances:
Deposits cannot be refunded for any other reason and can only be transferred to another programme starting in the same academic year.
If you request a refund for a tuition fee deposit as a result of exceptional circumstances, such as serious illness or bereavement, the decision will be made by schools or colleges on a case-by-case basis.
If you request a refund for a tuition fee deposit, your application will be automatically withdrawn. You should contact your admissions office if you want to have your application for the same programme reactivated. You will need to re-apply if you want to be considered for the same programme, or a different programme, in a subsequent year.
Refund requests must be made in writing (via email) to your school or college admissions team.
If your programme requires a deposit you will need to pay it to secure your place, unless you qualify for an exemption.
You will not need to pay a deposit if you:
If you have paid a deposit for a postgraduate degree programme but want to accept a place on a different postgraduate programme at the University, starting in the same academic year, your tuition fee deposit can be transferred to the new programme.
Your tuition fee deposit cannot be transferred to a different programme starting in a different academic year.
If we agree to your deferral request, and you have:

If you made no attempt to meet the offer conditions no refund will be given.If your UK student visa or ATAS clearance application is refused or rejected, except where refusal is a result of:a fraudulent visa applicationinsufficient fundssupply of incorrect documentsDeposits cannot be refunded for any other reason and can only be transferred to another programme starting in the same academic year.Making a refund requestIf you request a refund for a tuition fee deposit as a result of exceptional circumstances, such as serious illness or bereavement, the decision will be made by schools or colleges on a case-by-case basis.If you request a refund for a tuition fee deposit, your application will be automatically withdrawn. You should contact your admissions office if you want to have your application for the same programme reactivated. You will need to re-apply if you want to be considered for the same programme, or a different programme, in a subsequent year.Refund requests must be made in writing (via email) to your school or college admissions team.Contact details for your admissions team are provided on your programme page in our postgraduate degree finder. Find contact details in our postgraduate degree finderDeposit exemptionsIf your programme requires a deposit you will need to pay it to secure your place, unless you qualify for an exemption.You will not need to pay a deposit if you:are sponsored by a University of Edinburgh recognised sponsor or have a full scholarship covering your tuition fees. You must provide acceptable evidence, no later than the deadline by which the deposit would have been due.previously studied at the University of Edinburgh and received one of the following bursaries or scholarships:Rest of UK (RUK) Undergraduate BursaryScotland Accommodation BursaryUniversity of Edinburgh ScholarshipScotland ScholarshipAccess Edinburgh ScholarshipTransferring depositsIf you have paid a deposit for a postgraduate degree programme but want to accept a place on a different postgraduate programme at the University, starting in the same academic year, your tuition fee deposit can be transferred to the new programme.Your tuition fee deposit cannot be transferred to a different programme starting in a different academic year.DeferralsIf we agree to your deferral request, and you have:not yet paid a deposit - you will need to pay the deposit in order to secure the offer of the deferred placealready paid a deposit - we will retain the deposit and allocate it to the tuition fees due for the deferred place in the following yearIf we refuse your deferral request, and you have already paid a tuition fee deposit, a refund will be at the discretion of your school or college.School and college deposit policiesA number of our colleges and schools operate their own policy for tuition fee deposits. If you have applied for a programme at one of these schools or colleges, please refer to their own deposit pages.Business School depositsLaw School deposits: on-campus masters programmesLaw School deposits: online masters programmesMoray House School of Education and Sport depositsCollege of Medicine and Veterinary Medicine depositsCollege of Science and Engineering deposits

pages.content:
[HEADING] China
[HEADING] Postgraduate taught programmes
[HEADING] Specific grades required for each programme
[HEADING] Priority List of Chinese universities
[HEADING] PhD programmes
[HEADING] Further guidance on academic entry requirements
[HEADING] Degrees jointly awarded by Chinese and UK universities
[HEADING] English Language requirements
[HEADING] Applicant support
[HEADING] About Edinburgh
[HEADING] Student numbers
Postgraduate entry requirements for students from China.
Entry requirements to our programmes vary and programmes in great demand will require higher entry grades.
To apply, you should have:
Entry into our high-demand programmes will require higher grades. To find the required grades for each degree programme:
Band A: a minimum of 85% awarded by a university on our Priority List
Band B: a minimum of 80% awarded by a university on our Priority List
Band C: a minimum of 80%, awarded by a university on our Priority List
OR a minimum of 85% (“normal” level) from any recognised university
Band D: a minimum of 80% from any recognised university
For some universities listed there are further requirements around subject area or discipline and grading scales. Full details are given on the list.
Typically, entry to PhD study requires a masters degree in a related or relevant subject, and a research proposal.
However, entry requirements vary by programme, and you should check the detailed entry requirements are listed under each programme on the Degree Finder.
Degree Finder
How to write a research proposal
You can also obtain further guidance on admissions requirements from staff in the College Admissions Offices.
College of Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences
College of Medicine and Veterinary Medicine
College of Science and Engineering
If your degree was taught in China and jointly awarded by a Chinese and a UK university, you must meet our entry requirements with the grades that you achieve from each institution. The entry requirements for UK qualifications for each programme can be found on the Degree Finder.
Degree Finder
If you have studied on a 2+2 programme and transferred to a UK university to complete the second half of your degree, your final grades must meet our entry requirements for UK qualifications.
All applicants are required to demonstrate a level of English language competency, regardless of their nationality or country of residence. These requirements are listed by programme.
English Language advice
Specific English language requirement by programme
Our representative for China is Esther Sum.
You can contact us for advice and support by emailing:
futurestudents@ed.ac.uk
Browse our events calendar to see if we are hosting an event in your area:
Events calendar
Review student visa requirements on our Student Immigration Service website:
Student Immigration Service
Virtual Visit of the campus
UniBuddy - chat to our students
Open Days and events
There are over 5,000 students from China currently studying at the University of Edinburgh.
This article was published on
          2024-11-12
• a first degree from a university on our Priority List of Chinese universities or a recognised university.
• minimum grades between 80-85%.
• Search for a degree programme on the Degree Finder
• Check the programme’s ‘Band’ letter (A, B, C or D) listed under ‘entry requirements'.
• Find the entry requirements for each band shown below.
[GRID_TABLE]

 Priority List of Chinese universities (199.91 KB / PDF)


PhD programmesTypically, entry to PhD study requires a masters degree in a related or relevant subject, and a research proposal.However, entry requirements vary by programme, and you should check the detailed entry requirements are listed under each programme on the Degree Finder. Degree FinderHow to write a research proposalFurther guidance on academic entry requirementsYou can also obtain further guidance on admissions requirements from staff in the College Admissions Offices.College of Arts, Humanities and Social SciencesCollege of Medicine and Veterinary MedicineCollege of Science and EngineeringDegrees jointly awarded by Chinese and UK universitiesIf your degree was taught in China and jointly awarded by a Chinese and a UK university, you must meet our entry requirements with the grades that you achieve from each institution. The entry requirements for UK qualifications for each programme can be found on the Degree Finder.Degree FinderIf you have studied on a 2+2 programme and transferred to a UK university to complete the second half of your degree, your final grades must meet our entry requirements for UK qualifications.English Language requirementsAll applicants are required to demonstrate a level of English language competency, regardless of their nationality or country of residence. These requirements are listed by programme.English Language adviceSpecific English language requirement by programmeApplicant supportOur representative for China is Esther Sum.You can contact us for advice and support by emailing:futurestudents@ed.ac.ukBrowse our events calendar to see if we are hosting an event in your area:Events calendarReview student visa requirements on our Student Immigration Service website:Student Immigration ServiceAbout EdinburghVirtual Visit of the campusUniBuddy - chat to our studentsOpen Days and eventsStudent numbersThere are over 5,000 students from China currently studying at the University of Edinburgh.

[HEADING] Applying
[HEADING] Research degrees
[HEADING] Taught degrees
[HEADING] Choosing a postgraduate degree
[HEADING] Your application
Find out more about how to choose the most suitable postgraduate taught or research degree programme for you, and learn more about our application process.
Postgraduate research degrees involve an extended period of intensive, independent research, resulting in a significant contribution of original knowledge to your field.
A postgraduate taught qualification is normally for those who have completed an undergraduate degree and want to undertake more specialist training, or change their field of study.
There are many different routes in to academic study or research at postgraduate level, and deciding which is the best one for you will depend on your study and career objectives. This guide will help you choose the right path.
Applying to study at Edinburgh.

pages.title: Postgraduate study | The University of Edinburgh

pages.content:
[HEADING] Undergraduate or Postgraduate Taught Enquiries
If you have a question about applying to an undergraduate or postgraduate taught programme at the College of Science & Engineering, or if you have applied to us and have a question about your application, please complete our enquiry form. Postgraduate Research application enquiries should refer to our Contact us page.
This article was published on
          2024-05-20
[GRID_TABLE]
Undergraduate or Postgraduate Taught Enquiries





If you have a question about applying to an undergraduate or postgraduate taught programme at the College of Science & Engineering, or if you have applied to us and have a question about your application, please complete our enquiry form. Postgraduate Research application enquiries should refer to our Contact us page.







Title
- Select -MrMrsMsDrProf


First name



Family Name/Surname



Email address



What country are you from?


Please enter the name of your home country.



Have you already applied to the University of Edinburgh?
- Select -YesNo


What is your student ID number?



Have you previously contacted the University?
- None -YesNoNot sure


What level of study are you interested in?
- None -UndergraduatePostgraduate Taught (Masters)



What is the subject area of the degree that you are interested in studying?



What is the subject area of the degree that you are interested in studying?
- None -Biological SciencesEngineeringGeoSciencesMathematicsInformaticsPhysics and AstronomyChemistryOther - please enter


Enter other…





What School/College/University are you currently attending?



ENQUIRY











This question is for testing whether or not you are a human visitor and to prevent automated spam submissions.





I consent to the University processing the information I provide.


        The information you provide will enable us to respond to your enquiry. We will not use your information to send any communication not related to your enquiry.
        

        Your information may be retained for a maximum of 12 months from submission.

pages.content:
[HEADING] English language entry requirements
[HEADING] Programme requirements
[HEADING] Accepted English language qualifications
[HEADING] Degrees taught and assessed in English
[HEADING] Degrees supported by school qualifications
[HEADING] Transfers
[HEADING] Degrees from UK universities with campuses overseas
[HEADING] Degrees jointly awarded by the University of Edinburgh
[HEADING] Degrees awarded by a UK university with a partner university in China
[HEADING] Degrees awarded by the Open University
[HEADING] Online degrees
[HEADING] Other qualifications and tests
[HEADING] Expiry of qualifications
[HEADING] Two year expiry
[HEADING] Three and a half year expiry
[HEADING] Pre-sessional English for Academic Purposes
[HEADING] Professional qualifications
[HEADING] Certificates
[HEADING] Students who require a visa to study in the UK
[HEADING] Degree study
[HEADING] English language education
[HEADING] English language courses
[HEADING] Related Links
You must demonstrate a level of English language competency that will enable you to succeed in your studies, regardless of your nationality or where you live.
English language requirements vary between degree programmes and you should check you have the necessary qualifications before applying.
Find the specific language requirements for your chosen programme in our degree finder.
Postgraduate degree finder
We accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.
If you have already met our English language entry requirements for your programme at the time you apply, your application may be considered more competitive in selection than applications where you still need to take an English language test.
We accept an undergraduate degree, PGCE, PGDE or postgraduate degree, including a one-year Masters degree, that has been taught and assessed in English, either:
UKVI Majority English-speaking countries and territories
Approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries and regions
If you are not a national of a majority English-speaking country or region, then your degree must be no more than five years old at the start of the month in which your programme of study begins.
You may also meet our English language entry requirement if you can provide evidence of the following:
Evidence that your degree was taught and assessed in English should be in the form of a letter from the awarding university.
Undergraduate English language entry requirements
If you have transferred from a university where teaching and assessment are conducted in a language other than English to a university in a majority English-speaking country or region, or to an approved university in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, at least 50% of your studies must have been undertaken in English, including your final year of study.
We do not accept degrees awarded by UK universities where all study has taken place at an overseas campus in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, unless they are on the list of approved universities.
We accept degrees jointly awarded by the University of Edinburgh with partner universities in non-majority English speaking countries where teaching and assessment are conducted in English, even if the partner universities are not on the list of approved universities.
We accept dual/joint degree qualifications awarded by a UK university with a partner university in China, where the degree is licensed by the Chinese Ministry of Education and is included on the Ministry’s published list of approved joint degrees.
A full list of the approved degrees is available in spreadsheet (.xlsx) format:
If you need to request this information in an alternative format, please contact us via email: futurestudents@ed.ac.uk
We only accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet our academic English requirement if you are a national of a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).
We do not accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet visa English requirements.
We do not accept degrees taught and assessed entirely online except for those awarded by the University of Edinburgh, or the Open University provided you meet the criteria defined above.
We also accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.
The qualifications we accept meet both our English language proficiency requirements and the minimum standards for Student route visas.
Your English language qualification must be no more than three and a half years old from the start of the month in which the programme you are applying to study begins, unless you are using IELTS, TOEFL or Trinity ISE, in which case it must be no more than two years old on the first of the month in which the degree begins.
International English Language Testing System (internet-based or at any IELTS test centre)
English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept IELTS One Skill Retake, IELTS General, IELTS for UKVI General or IELTS Life Skills for UKVI to meet our English language requirements.
PTE Academic
(including Home Edition)
Internet-based or Paper Edition Test of English as a Foreign Language.
English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept TOEFL MyBest Score to meet our English language requirements.
We also accept satisfactory completion of our English for Academic Purposes programme or the University of Glasgow Pre-Sessional English programme as meeting our English language requirements. You must complete the programme no more than two years and one month before the start of the month in which the degree you are applying to study begins.
Pre-sessional English for Academic Purposes
The following professional registrations can be accepted as meeting English language requirements:
If you are not a national of and are no longer domiciled in a majority English-speaking country or region, your professional qualification must be no more than three and a half years old at the beginning of your programme of study.
We will need to verify your qualifications and/or test results. If your certificates are not in English you will also need to submit a certified translation.
Submitting your certificates
In addition to our English language proficiency requirements, the UK Home Office sets its own minimum standards for applicants who require a Student route visa to study in the UK.
If you require a Student route visa to study in the UK, the English qualification that you use for admission to a postgraduate degree must be included in our list of accepted qualifications, unless you are a national of a majority English-speaking country or territory as defined by UK Visas and Immigration (UKVI).
Majority English speaking countries and territories
If you are interested in our English language programmes as preparation for degree entry you must have an IELTS for UKVI test from a UKVI-approved test centre.
UKVI approved test centres
If you do not have the English grades we require for entry, you can improve your language skills through our range of English courses.
English language courses at Edinburgh
University policy on English language entry
This article was published on
          2024-11-12
• In a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).
• On our list of approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries.
• You have a school qualification which meets our English language entry requirements for undergraduate study; AND
• You began a degree within three and a half years of achieving your school qualification, which was taught and assessed in English at a recognised university not otherwise accepted for English language purposes; AND
• That you successfully completed that degree within five years old of the start of the month in which your programme of study begins.
• Membership of the Faculty of Dental Surgery (MFDS)/ Membership of the Faculty of Dentistry (MFD)
• NHS Dental Vocational (Foundation) Training and Dental Core Training
• Overseas Registration Examination (ORE)
• General Medical Council (GMC) (must be Registered with a licence to practise)
• Membership of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (MRCV)
• Registration with the Health Care Professionals Council (HCPC)
• Membership of the Royal College of Physicians
• Royal College of Surgeons
• The Membership Examination of the Surgical Royal Colleges of Great Britain (MRCS)
• Irish Medical Council (IMC)
• General Dental Council (GDC)
[HTML_TABLE]
IELTS Academic / IELTS Academic for UKVI and IELTS Academic Online | International English Language Testing System (internet-based or at any IELTS test centre)English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept IELTS One Skill Retake, IELTS General, IELTS for UKVI General or IELTS Life Skills for UKVI to meet our English language requirements.
PTE Academic | We do not accept PTE Academic Online to meet our English language requirements.
TOEFL-iBT(including Home Edition) | Internet-based or Paper Edition Test of English as a Foreign Language.English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept TOEFL MyBest Score to meet our English language requirements.
Trinity ISE | Trinity Integrated Skills in English
Oxford ELLT Global and Oxford ELLT Digital | Oxford English Language Level Test
[HTML_TABLE]
C1 Advanced | C1 Advanced, formerly known as Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE)
C2 Proficiency | C2 Proficiency, formerly known as Cambridge English: Proficiency (CPE)
[GRID_TABLE]

If you need to request this information in an alternative format, please contact us via email: futurestudents@ed.ac.ukDegrees awarded by the Open UniversityWe only accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet our academic English requirement if you are a national of a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).UKVI Majority English-speaking countries and territoriesWe do not accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet visa English requirements.Online degreesWe do not accept degrees taught and assessed entirely online except for those awarded by the University of Edinburgh, or the Open University provided you meet the criteria defined above.Other qualifications and testsWe also accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.The qualifications we accept meet both our English language proficiency requirements and the minimum standards for Student route visas.Expiry of qualificationsYour English language qualification must be no more than three and a half years old from the start of the month in which the programme you are applying to study begins, unless you are using IELTS, TOEFL or Trinity ISE, in which case it must be no more than two years old on the first of the month in which the degree begins.  Two year expiryIELTS Academic / IELTS Academic for UKVI and IELTS Academic OnlineInternational English Language Testing System (internet-based or at any IELTS test centre)English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept IELTS One Skill Retake, IELTS General, IELTS for UKVI General or IELTS Life Skills for UKVI to meet our English language requirements.PTE Academic  We do not accept PTE Academic Online to meet our English language requirements.TOEFL-iBT(including Home Edition)Internet-based or Paper Edition Test of English as a Foreign Language.English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept TOEFL MyBest Score to meet our English language requirements.Trinity ISETrinity Integrated Skills in EnglishOxford ELLT Global and Oxford ELLT DigitalOxford English Language Level TestThree and a half year expiryC1 Advanced   C1 Advanced, formerly known as Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE)C2 ProficiencyC2 Proficiency, formerly known as Cambridge English: Proficiency (CPE)Pre-sessional English for Academic PurposesWe also accept satisfactory completion of our English for Academic Purposes programme or the University of Glasgow Pre-Sessional English programme as meeting our English language requirements. You must complete the programme no more than two years and one month before the start of the month in which the degree you are applying to study begins.Pre-sessional English for Academic PurposesProfessional qualificationsThe following professional registrations can be accepted as meeting English language requirements:Membership of the Faculty of Dental Surgery (MFDS)/ Membership of the Faculty of Dentistry (MFD)NHS Dental Vocational (Foundation) Training and Dental Core TrainingOverseas Registration Examination (ORE)General Medical Council (GMC) (must be Registered with a licence to practise)Membership of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (MRCV)Registration with the Health Care Professionals Council (HCPC)Membership of the Royal College of PhysiciansRoyal College of SurgeonsThe Membership Examination of the Surgical Royal Colleges of Great Britain (MRCS)Irish Medical Council (IMC)General Dental Council (GDC)If you are not a national of and are no longer domiciled in a majority English-speaking country or region, your professional qualification must be no more than three and a half years old at the beginning of your programme of study.CertificatesWe will need to verify your qualifications and/or test results. If your certificates are not in English you will also need to submit a certified translation.Submitting your certificatesStudents who require a visa to study in the UKIn addition to our English language proficiency requirements, the UK Home Office sets its own minimum standards for applicants who require a Student route visa to study in the UK.Degree studyIf you require a Student route visa to study in the UK, the English qualification that you use for admission to a postgraduate degree must be included in our list of accepted qualifications, unless you are a national of a majority English-speaking country or territory as defined by UK Visas and Immigration (UKVI).Majority English speaking countries and territoriesEnglish language educationIf you are interested in our English language programmes as preparation for degree entry you must have an IELTS for UKVI test from a UKVI-approved test centre.UKVI approved test centresEnglish language coursesIf you do not have the English grades we require for entry, you can improve your language skills through our range of English courses.English language courses at EdinburghRelated LinksUniversity policy on English language entry
[GRID_TABLE]
English language entry requirements





You must demonstrate a level of English language competency that will enable you to succeed in your studies, regardless of your nationality or where you live.



 
Programme requirementsEnglish language requirements vary between degree programmes and you should check you have the necessary qualifications before applying.Find the specific language requirements for your chosen programme in our degree finder.Postgraduate degree finderAccepted English language qualificationsWe accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.If you have already met our English language entry requirements for your programme at the time you apply, your application may be considered more competitive in selection than applications where you still need to take an English language test. Degrees taught and assessed in EnglishWe accept an undergraduate degree, PGCE, PGDE or postgraduate degree, including a one-year Masters degree, that has been taught and assessed in English, either:In a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).UKVI Majority English-speaking countries and territoriesorOn our list of approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries.Approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries and regionsIf you are not a national of a majority English-speaking country or region, then your degree must be no more than five years old at the start of the month in which your programme of study begins.Degrees supported by school qualificationsYou may also meet our English language entry requirement if you can provide evidence of the following: You have a school qualification which meets our English language entry requirements for undergraduate study; ANDYou began a degree within three and a half years of achieving your school qualification, which was taught and assessed in English at a recognised university not otherwise accepted for English language purposes; ANDThat you successfully completed that degree within five years old of the start of the month in which your programme of study begins. Evidence that your degree was taught and assessed in English should be in the form of a letter from the awarding university. Undergraduate English language entry requirements TransfersIf you have transferred from a university where teaching and assessment are conducted in a language other than English to a university in a majority English-speaking country or region, or to an approved university in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, at least 50% of your studies must have been undertaken in English, including your final year of study.Degrees from UK universities with campuses overseasWe do not accept degrees awarded by UK universities where all study has taken place at an overseas campus in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, unless they are on the list of approved universities.Degrees jointly awarded by the University of EdinburghWe accept degrees jointly awarded by the University of Edinburgh with partner universities in non-majority English speaking countries where teaching and assessment are conducted in English, even if the partner universities are not on the list of approved universities.Degrees awarded by a UK university with a partner university in ChinaWe accept dual/joint degree qualifications awarded by a UK university with a partner university in China, where the degree is licensed by the Chinese Ministry of Education and is included on the Ministry’s published list of approved joint degrees.A full list of the approved degrees is available in spreadsheet (.xlsx) format:

Programme requirementsEnglish language requirements vary between degree programmes and you should check you have the necessary qualifications before applying.Find the specific language requirements for your chosen programme in our degree finder.Postgraduate degree finderAccepted English language qualificationsWe accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.If you have already met our English language entry requirements for your programme at the time you apply, your application may be considered more competitive in selection than applications where you still need to take an English language test. Degrees taught and assessed in EnglishWe accept an undergraduate degree, PGCE, PGDE or postgraduate degree, including a one-year Masters degree, that has been taught and assessed in English, either:In a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).UKVI Majority English-speaking countries and territoriesorOn our list of approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries.Approved universities in non-majority English-speaking countries and regionsIf you are not a national of a majority English-speaking country or region, then your degree must be no more than five years old at the start of the month in which your programme of study begins.Degrees supported by school qualificationsYou may also meet our English language entry requirement if you can provide evidence of the following: You have a school qualification which meets our English language entry requirements for undergraduate study; ANDYou began a degree within three and a half years of achieving your school qualification, which was taught and assessed in English at a recognised university not otherwise accepted for English language purposes; ANDThat you successfully completed that degree within five years old of the start of the month in which your programme of study begins. Evidence that your degree was taught and assessed in English should be in the form of a letter from the awarding university. Undergraduate English language entry requirements TransfersIf you have transferred from a university where teaching and assessment are conducted in a language other than English to a university in a majority English-speaking country or region, or to an approved university in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, at least 50% of your studies must have been undertaken in English, including your final year of study.Degrees from UK universities with campuses overseasWe do not accept degrees awarded by UK universities where all study has taken place at an overseas campus in a non-majority English-speaking country or region, unless they are on the list of approved universities.Degrees jointly awarded by the University of EdinburghWe accept degrees jointly awarded by the University of Edinburgh with partner universities in non-majority English speaking countries where teaching and assessment are conducted in English, even if the partner universities are not on the list of approved universities.Degrees awarded by a UK university with a partner university in ChinaWe accept dual/joint degree qualifications awarded by a UK university with a partner university in China, where the degree is licensed by the Chinese Ministry of Education and is included on the Ministry’s published list of approved joint degrees.A full list of the approved degrees is available in spreadsheet (.xlsx) format:
Document

 List of approved UK-China joint partnership programmes 2024 (49.23 KB / XLSX)
If you need to request this information in an alternative format, please contact us via email: futurestudents@ed.ac.ukDegrees awarded by the Open UniversityWe only accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet our academic English requirement if you are a national of a majority English-speaking country or territory, as defined by UK Visas & Immigration (UKVI).UKVI Majority English-speaking countries and territoriesWe do not accept degrees awarded by the Open University to meet visa English requirements.Online degreesWe do not accept degrees taught and assessed entirely online except for those awarded by the University of Edinburgh, or the Open University provided you meet the criteria defined above.Other qualifications and testsWe also accept a wide range of international English qualifications and English language tests.The qualifications we accept meet both our English language proficiency requirements and the minimum standards for Student route visas.Expiry of qualificationsYour English language qualification must be no more than three and a half years old from the start of the month in which the programme you are applying to study begins, unless you are using IELTS, TOEFL or Trinity ISE, in which case it must be no more than two years old on the first of the month in which the degree begins.  Two year expiryIELTS Academic / IELTS Academic for UKVI and IELTS Academic OnlineInternational English Language Testing System (internet-based or at any IELTS test centre)English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept IELTS One Skill Retake, IELTS General, IELTS for UKVI General or IELTS Life Skills for UKVI to meet our English language requirements.PTE Academic  We do not accept PTE Academic Online to meet our English language requirements.TOEFL-iBT(including Home Edition)Internet-based or Paper Edition Test of English as a Foreign Language.English requirements must be met in a single test. We do not accept TOEFL MyBest Score to meet our English language requirements.Trinity ISETrinity Integrated Skills in EnglishOxford ELLT Global and Oxford ELLT DigitalOxford English Language Level TestThree and a half year expiryC1 Advanced   C1 Advanced, formerly known as Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE)C2 ProficiencyC2 Proficiency, formerly known as Cambridge English: Proficiency (CPE)Pre-sessional English for Academic PurposesWe also accept satisfactory completion of our English for Academic Purposes programme or the University of Glasgow Pre-Sessional English programme as meeting our English language requirements. You must complete the programme no more than two years and one month before the start of the month in which the degree you are applying to study begins.Pre-sessional English for Academic PurposesProfessional qualificationsThe following professional registrations can be accepted as meeting English language requirements:Membership of the Faculty of Dental Surgery (MFDS)/ Membership of the Faculty of Dentistry (MFD)NHS Dental Vocational (Foundation) Training and Dental Core TrainingOverseas Registration Examination (ORE)General Medical Council (GMC) (must be Registered with a licence to practise)Membership of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (MRCV)Registration with the Health Care Professionals Council (HCPC)Membership of the Royal College of PhysiciansRoyal College of SurgeonsThe Membership Examination of the Surgical Royal Colleges of Great Britain (MRCS)Irish Medical Council (IMC)General Dental Council (GDC)If you are not a national of and are no longer domiciled in a majority English-speaking country or region, your professional qualification must be no more than three and a half years old at the beginning of your programme of study.CertificatesWe will need to verify your qualifications and/or test results. [HEADING] Prospective postgraduates
[HEADING] Scholarship search
[HEADING] Funding for UK students
[HEADING] Funding for international students
[HEADING] Online Learning Scholarships
[HEADING] Tuition Fee Alumni Scholarships
[HEADING] Tuition Fees
[HEADING] Advice for managing your money
[HEADING] Education Beyond Borders postgraduate scholarship
[HEADING] Mastercard Foundation Scholars Program
[HEADING] The Alternative Guide to Postgraduate Funding
[HEADING] Pre-Sessional English Programme Graduate Scholarship
Information on funding opportunities and tuition fees for prospective postgraduate students.
Search for Bursaries, Scholarships and other Financial Aid available to prospective students
In addition to financial assistance provided by Research Councils and charitable trusts, the University offers a number of general and subject-specific funding schemes.
In addition to financial assistance provided by UK Government agencies and external funding sources, the University offers a number of general and subject-specific funding schemes.
The University offers several scholarships specifically for online, part-time postgraduate programmes.
The University of Edinburgh offers two tuition fee scholarship schemes for alumni of the University.
Tuition fee information for postgraduate students including tuition fee status, fee policy and tuition fee discounts.
Information to help you estimate how much it will cost to study at the University of Edinburgh.
The University of Edinburgh is offering up to 30 scholarships for a full-time postgraduate programme at the University of Edinburgh starting in September 2025.
The Mastercard Foundation Scholars Program aims to make a meaningful impact in addressing the climate crisis. The Program dedicated to nurturing a community of talented, entrepreneurial, and compassionate leaders from across Sub-Saharan Africa. The Program empowers young people with the necessary knowledge, skills, and networks to drive sustainable transitions by offering a range of exceptional sustainability-focused postgraduate opportunities at the University of Edinburgh.
If you’re seeking funding for postgraduate studies, you can independently register for the Alternative Guide to Postgraduate Funding. This resource offers a database of funding opportunities, along with guidance and tools to help with grant applications.
The Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme Graduate Scholarship consists of a 10% fee discount on full time taught postgraduate degree fees and is available to students with international fee status who are domiciled in one of 9 countries listed below, have successfully completed the Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme in academic year 2025/26 and have accepted an offer of study for a full time postgraduate taught degree programme in 2026/27.
This article was published on
          2024-07-29

Advice for managing your money





Information to help you estimate how much it will cost to study at the University of Edinburgh.











Education Beyond Borders postgraduate scholarship





The University of Edinburgh is offering up to 30 scholarships for a full-time postgraduate programme at the University of Edinburgh starting in September 2025.











Mastercard Foundation Scholars Program





The Mastercard Foundation Scholars Program aims to make a meaningful impact in addressing the climate crisis. The Program dedicated to nurturing a community of talented, entrepreneurial, and compassionate leaders from across Sub-Saharan Africa. The Program empowers young people with the necessary knowledge, skills, and networks to drive sustainable transitions by offering a range of exceptional sustainability-focused postgraduate opportunities at the University of Edinburgh.











The Alternative Guide to Postgraduate Funding





If you’re seeking funding for postgraduate studies, you can independently register for the Alternative Guide to Postgraduate Funding. This resource offers a database of funding opportunities, along with guidance and tools to help with grant applications. 











Pre-Sessional English Programme Graduate Scholarship 





The Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme Graduate Scholarship consists of a 10% fee discount on full time taught postgraduate degree fees and is available to students with international fee status who are domiciled in one of 9 countries listed below, have successfully completed the Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme in academic year 2025/26 and have accepted an offer of study for a full time postgraduate taught degree programme in 2026/27.

The Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme Graduate Scholarship consists of a 10% fee discount on full time taught postgraduate degree fees and is available to students with international fee status who are domiciled in one of 9 countries listed below, have successfully completed the Postgraduate Pre-Sessional English Programme in academic year 2025/26 and have accepted an offer of study for a full time postgraduate taught degree programme in 2026/27.

In addition to financial assistance provided by Research Councils and charitable trusts, the University offers a number of general and subject-specific funding schemes.











Funding for international students





In addition to financial assistance provided by UK Government agencies and external funding sources, the University offers a number of general and subject-specific funding schemes.

The University offers several scholarships specifically for online, part-time postgraduate programmes.

The University of Edinburgh offers two tuition fee scholarship schemes for alumni of the University.











Tuition Fees





Tuition fee information for postgraduate students including tuition fee status, fee policy and tuition fee discounts.

Education Beyond Borders postgraduate scholarship





The University of Edinburgh is offering up to 30 scholarships for a full-time postgraduate programme at the University of Edinburgh starting in September 2025.

The Mastercard Foundation Scholars Program aims to make a meaningful impact in addressing the climate crisis. The Program dedicated to nurturing a community of talented, entrepreneurial, and compassionate leaders from across Sub-Saharan Africa. The Program empowers young people with the necessary knowledge, skills, and networks to drive sustainable transitions by offering a range of exceptional sustainability-focused postgraduate opportunities at the University of Edinburgh.
